Nancy Mitford wrote between the world wars and often takes a witty look at upper middle class English society.Barbara Pym, another novelist of the mid-20th century, writes with a shrewd eye particularly observing the lives of single women. Though her novels may seem like sketches of small-town life, her wit, clever use of dialogue, and unsettling undercurrents of tragedy prove her books have staying power. Her novel, Quartet of Autumn, was nominated for the Booker Prize. Jane Gardam's novels plumb the depths of the human experience. Her novel, God on the Rocks, was short-listed for the Booker Prize and she continues to write for the BBC, reviews for newspapers, and as a novelist. #hatfieldpubliclibrary

Good news! There is a robust local network of food support services available to make sure no one goes hungry. It can be confusing to navigate the various services so here's a breakdown of what’s available to Hatfield residents of all ages.

For kids ages 0-18:
Grab & Go food service at the Hatfield Elementary School are served on Tuesday mornings. They provide a package of four lunches and three breakfasts each week. For more information and to sign up: http://hatfieldps.net/district-school-information/food-services

Grab & Go food service at Smith Vocational is served on Monday and Wednesday mornings. For more information: https://www.smithtec.org/

For Adults and families with food insecurity:
The Northampton Survival Center has partnered with Grow Food Northampton and Community Action Pioneer Valley to deliver food to various local sites. For more information: https://www.northamptonsurvival.org/

For Seniors:
The Hatfield Council on Aging delivers meals to Hatfield seniors in need. For more information contact the director, Geralyn Rodgers, at 413-247-9003.

Amber, our cataloguer extraordinaire, has a few good reads to recommend this weekend:

If you haven't read the trilogy beginning with A Discovery of Witches by Deborah Harkness, you are in for a treat. The first book is a fantastical love story, the second is an immersive journey back in time, and the third is a thrilling, scientific tale that wraps up the story and leaves room for spin-offs.

Class Mom by Laurie Gelman is just a really funny read about parents and kids in school. It is a good reminder not to take ourselves too seriously! At this point it's almost nostalgic...

Small Admissions by Amy Poeppel is another funny book about a woman facing adversity in the world of New York City private school admissions. She takes life on in the strangest ways but with a smile.
These books and many more are available on Libby with your HPL library card.

MAY 21 ANNUAL MEETING PROGRAM POSTPONED. After much consideration, the Hatfield Historical Society Board has decided to postpone the in-person program to introduce our oral history project at the Hatfield American Legion to a time when everyone will feel comfortable gathering. And since we don’t yet know when that will be, we are not setting a new date at this time. We hope you will understand this decision.

BUT, the debut of the VIRTUAL EXHIBIT, “Fifty Years Later: Hatfield Vietnam War Veterans Share Their Stories,” is still scheduled for Memorial Day of this year, and we will let you know once it’s finished. This new website will feature full interviews, highlighted clips and images for each of the 10 in-country Vietnam veterans and one Vietnam War nurse, telling stories that have mostly not been told outside of veterans’ circles.

Hatfield Historical Museum is with Patricia Cady and Pat Douglas.
April 9 at 11:30 PM ·

REST IN PEACE, PAT CADY (1935-2020). The Hatfield Historical Society is very sad to lose one of its board members, a past president and a dear friend. For more than a decade, Pat was one of the prime organizers of the Historical Society’s Hatfield Fall Festival and the Annual Jim Labbee Memorial Antique Classic Car, Truck & Tractor Show. Pat (Labbee) Cady grew up in Hatfield, raised her kids here, was a Brownie leader and Hatfield’s first female police officer (see photo). She’s also been a world-traveling member of the Young@Heart Chorus since 2006, even participating in a recent Zoom rehearsal (see their Facebook page).

Pat had stories about most everything, and she let us record her on a few occasions, so check back for some of those, coming soon. We’ll miss her terribly!

A Word on Exercise Intensity.

Dear Fitness Friends,
As you know, I’m a huge proponent for daily exercise for mind and body. This includes a minimum of 30 minutes daily. In addition to the obvious benefits of mood and general health, there is evidence that moderate intensity exercise improves immune function, the body’s ability to fight infection.

When exercise is taken from the moderate to the intense zone, such as running a marathon type exertion, there is a relative drop in immune function. That’s why many marathon runners, cross fitters, and triathletes get a cold 48-72 hours after a period of extreme exertion. I’m attaching a link on this phenomenon.

So.... my best advice:
1) Exercise every day for a minimum of 30 minutes
2) Outside is great if possible both for the fresh air and mental benefits
3) This is NOT the time to “crush”’your workout, not the time to go for the “max”
4) Keep encouraging everyone in your life to get off the couch and get outside and move
#exercise #prevention #movement 💪🏻

https://drjordanmetzl.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/ExercisingWhenSick.pdf

Social Media Dangers Exposed by Mom Posing as 11-Year-Old

Wait Until 8th
February 27 at 3:30 PM ·

A 37-year old mom goes undercover as an 11-year old girl to expose the dangers facing kids on social media platforms like Instagram, Snapchat, TikTok, and Kik. Left unsupervised, young children can be exposed to online predators, grooming, and psychological abuse within minutes.

This story is heartbreaking but important. Parents, if your kids have access to a smartphone and social media, they need you. They need your help to navigate the dangerous waters online. They need you to set healthy boundaries to help keep them safe. They need you to monitor how their online world is unfolding. They need you to prepare them for not if but when they are asked to send a nude picture or meet up with a stranger. They need you to talk to them about sexting, child predators and grooming. They need you.

Stay tuned for resources to help soon from Wait Until 8th. We are about to launch a digital training program for families to help kids across the country use technology safely, appropriately and moderately.

post_text: 5th graders visited the Old Burying Ground by the American Legion last week. Students completed a scavenger hunt examining some primary sources (grave markers) from our local Hatfield history. They found markers dating back to the early 1700's! After this we completed an art project. Students examined art work on the gravestones after the scavenger hunt. Mrs. Gworek then led students in a project in which students created a gravestone drawing. We are so lucky to have such rich local history. It was really cool to incorporate this into our curriculum.
